details.body:
The Courts have established as a clear general principle that the cost of travelling from an employee's home to his or her normal place of work is not travel in the performance of the duties, see [EIM31650](http://www.hmrc.gov.uk/manuals/eimanual/EIM31650.htm). The expense merely puts the employee into a position to perform his or her duties. The cases that have established this principle are:
Cook v Knott2TC246
Revell v Directors of Elworthy Bros & Co Ltd3TC12
Andrews v Astley8TC589
Ricketts v Colquhoun10TC118, see [EIM31641](http://www.hmrc.gov.uk/manuals/eimanual/EIM31641.htm)
Nolder v Walters15TC380
Burton v Rednall35TC435
Parikh v Sleeman63TC75, see [EIM32360](http://www.hmrc.gov.uk/manuals/eimanual/EIM32360.htm)
Miners v Atkinson68TC629, see [EIM32380](http://www.hmrc.gov.uk/manuals/eimanual/EIM32380.htm)
Kirkwood v Evans74TC481, see [EIM32374](http://www.hmrc.gov.uk/manuals/eimanual/EIM32374.htm)
The only exceptions to this rule are: * travel from home to a temporary workplace, see [EIM32000](http://www.hmrc.gov.uk/manuals/eimanual/EIM32000.htm) * where the employee has a travelling appointment, see [EIM32366](http://www.hmrc.gov.uk/manuals/eimanual/EIM32366.htm) * where the employee’s home is a place of work **and** the place where the employee lives is dictated by the requirements of the job, see [EIM32370](http://www.hmrc.gov.uk/manuals/eimanual/EIM32370.htm) * where the duties of the employment are carried out wholly or partly outside the UK, see [EIM34020](http://www.hmrc.gov.uk/manuals/eimanual/EIM34020.htm) * where a non-domiciled employee is working in the UK, see [EIM35030](http://www.hmrc.gov.uk/manuals/eimanual/EIM35030.htm) * emergency call-outs see [EIM32386](http://www.hmrc.gov.uk/manuals/eimanual/EIM32386.htm).
